pros: Decent pay against the market average (although duties do not match title), generous PTO, can be some flexibility in your schedule for many positions, get your own laptop
cons:
Ridiculous expectations, no communication from corporate to leadership, huge disconnect from corporate to the bakeries, technology overhauls are done at cut-rate budgets, making the “new” worse than the old, the working environment is toxic at best, nobody knows where to go for information, the turnover in salary staff is incredible.
Advice to Management
Look into why your people are leaving. This turnover is not sustainable. Maybe send your corporate people into a bakery before making tech changes to ensure the change actually meets their needs. Stop bragging/advertising the work from home life that is not afforded to everybody. Offer a better defined career path. Change the culture in bakeries to accept some flexibility and work-life balance. If you aren’t willing to work 14 hours a day, you are seen as being difficult. No matter that every time someone quits, everyone who is left just picks up their roles for months until they are replaced (or indefinitely because the company has decided not to fill the role). When we say we are stretched thin, trust us - we are!
Helpful (1

pros: Amazing brands with global reach allowing for a wide range of collaboration with cross-functional teams. Allows for building product development skills and technical growth. Management is supportive and allows for independent decision-making with trust to live company's value of "Act like an owner". Excellent benefits, with close to 9% 401k contribution. Health benefits are comprehensive as per big corp. standards. Flexible WFH policy. Very pleasant group of individuals in day-to-day work and good morale.
cons:
Lack of raises, promotions, and support for individual's growth. Very select few get promoted based on management favorites. It takes years to get even a 5% bump in salary. Big turnaround after few years of experience for many folks ~5 years experience.
Advice to Management

review_title: Easy work and okay compensation. But hours are volatile and training for heavy machinery is not provided.
pros: Halfway decent compensation, .53 cents per mile while driving on the clock, independent work without the boss breathing down your neck. Easy work once you get the hang of it after a couple of weeks on the job.
cons:
Hours go way up and way down unexpectedly. Some weeks you may get 35 hours, some 10 hours. The mileage compensation only begins after the first 25 miles on your way to the first store, so if you wake up and drive to a store 24 miles away, you get zero mileage compensation for that. However, you still get compensation for all miles driven in between stores, but the same rule applies for going home after your last store. If after your last store, you have to drive 24 miles to get home, no compensation. While working, you are representing the company and although you don't write the orders, you will often be the recipient of frustrations by the store managers. The biggest con of all is the use of motorized FORKLIFT JACKS. It is Mondelez policy that no one can use them for concerns regarding safety. However, it is basically a requirement to use it anyways if you don't want to spend all day at one store wasting your time waiting for a store manager to get off their butts, do their job, and get it down for you. Its nearly impossible unless you're willing to wait sometimes an HOUR for them to bring down ONE pallet of backstock. Because you're forced to use them against company policy, if an accident happens, you are responsible. Considering this, don't even apply unless you have experience using forklift jacks unless you're willing to put yourself at risk by trying to learn it on your own. Prepare to be called in a lot if you're good at your job. When other people call in sick or can't make it to a store, the bosses will lean on you as a crutch if they know that they can count on you always saying yes. Totally inconsistent scheduling, for most shifts I was only notified of them less than a day prior, which makes planning anything in your personal life almost impossible since you never know if you're working tomorrow.
Advice to Management
Fix the scheduling problem and give your workers at least 3 days notice before any shift unless they are covering for someone who called in. Train your employees to use the forklift jack. If that isn't possible for whatever reason, then consistently stress to the store managers the importance of getting pallets down in a timely manner. Putting worker's livelihoods and safety at risk for not going to bat for them with store managers or training them to use heavy machinery is downright wrong.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Fix the scheduling problem and give your workers at least 3 days notice before any shift unless they are covering for someone who called in. Train your employees to use the forklift jack. If that isn't possible for whatever reason, then consistently stress to the store managers the importance of getting pallets down in a timely manner. Putting worker's livelihoods and safety at risk for not going to bat for them with store managers or training them to use heavy machinery is downright wrong.

pros: Good benefits, company car, some truly wonderful store managers and merchandisers that can make certain days a joy
cons:
Increased programming and increased leveraging of Computer-Assisted Ordering from store's corporate office removes sales aspect of position. Every inch of stores are scripted and you only get whatever the account team negotiates. Still expected to hit objectives from the days of more aggressive selling, leading to heavy backstock which leads to angry customers and waste. Company hammers on no overtime, yet will schedule as many as 17 hours in one day for coverage on understaffed territory. Basically encouraging working off the clock. Objectives can be political. Increasing "anti-vendor" attitude in stores. I can go on and on with little gripes. Mainly, changing modes of operation in the grocery business leads to questions about the future of this type of business.
Advice to Management

review_title: Used to be a great place to work for R&D professionals
pros: Flexibility, nice coworkers, large global R&D community, lots to learn, good 401K, good PTO policy.
cons:
Lots of turnover. Parking is absurd, open seating is awkward and unproductive. At least let people keep the same desks everyday. Lots of cost cutting around travel. Salaries are below market. I’d say constant change of leadership is exhausting, but that happens everywhere. 90% of the senior leaders in this company behave like celebrities instead of serving and supporting their people. By senior leaders I mean those who are above section managers. I’ve worked at other large companies and never have seen anything like this. It makes for a top heavy almost monarchy-like culture where all the employees are constantly scrambling to satisfy the latest whim of the King or Queen in charge.
Advice to Management
Senior management needs to be more humble and approachable.

review_title: No work, life balance as they preach.
pros: I am not sure yet....still thinking........
cons:
They preach,."Home, Life Balance. Nope, it all about them and only them. They make your schedule and will change it, the night before without informing you. The scheduling is a joke. One day you work 3.5 hours, then the following day you work 9.75. Explanation I received....a computer makes up the schedule. That is BS! I know for a fact that is incorrect. They give us a phone, but management will still text your personal. No stipend, no permission to contact me on personal phone. Oh and they will call you on PTO or vacation and demand you call them back, on your PTO or vacation. I have witnessed it first hand. No one is held accountable for anything...it is so ridiculous. Sales people are also merchandisers. They throw way more product than an actual merchandiser does. Training is an absolute joke. They give you some paperwork, go over it...hand you a cellphone and iPad and expect you to learn it from others. Online classes have Zero to do with what your position is. 95% of what they told me in the interviews, to get the job, was a blatant lie. Turn over rate is very high because moral is so low.
Advice to Management
Come out to the field and talk with the people at ground zero. You will get and earful!!

pros: You choose your own start time, as long as it's early. Nobody is hovering over you. You figure out ways to do your job best in the stores assigned to you, because no two stores are alike and each store changes frequently. Store employees are usually friendly. You get a sense of satisfaction after spending a short amount of time in a store and seeing how much improvement you can make in the shopper's experience.
cons:
You're treated like a lone wolf out there on the edge of the wilderness. Nobody communicates with you. Store backrooms can be very difficult to maneuver. Most retail employees are not going to make your job easier. You have to figure things out and work around a LOT of obstacles and people. You don't get feedback or any ongoing coaching. You have to make a lot of noise to get attention to a problem.
Advice to Management
Teach managers of merchandisers to communicate with their direct reports and to communicate more frequently.

pros: Little to no supervision, easy work, flexible for part time employees.
cons:
Constant messages from sales rep regarding instructions. No stability to the culture leading to abuse of employees who actually show up to work. No notification of work schedule or assignments until late the night before. Supervisors trying to change your schedule in the middle of the week. Seriously the culture is so bad that even the supervisory positions have clueless people who continue to be employed because no one wants their job. This leads to dissatisfaction among the lower level employees who just get shat on.

review_title: Big Company that feels like a Big Company
pros:
- Starting salary is competitive with similar companies 
- REALLY flexible work environment: you can work from home when needed and work the hours that work for your schedule
- GREAT PTO (I had 15 when I started my first year out of college)
- People are generally competent (but very few people at the bottom of the organization are that impressive) 
- Processes are in place for everything (but they are so complicated and hard to figure out)
- Aware of their shortfallings in complexity 
- Ability to work internationally
cons:
- There is so much red tape that it takes YEARS to get anything done. made me want to pull my hair out
- Managers vary a lot in their abilities as managers
- Do not get any cross functional visibility. Everything is very siloed
Advice to Management
Keep the culture because that is the reason people stay as long as they do
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the culture because that is the reason people stay as long as they do

pros: Typical benefits of Fortune 500 company. 2 weeks PTO to start, then additional week every 5 years. Diverse employee population. Pay is still fair for local market, but has declined significantly over the past 5 years when they were a pay scale leader. Benefits are good, includes 1-day a week remote/work-from-home day.
cons:
Promotional training is poor or non-existent. Frequently managers don't have the skills to train their own team. Strong emphasis on zero-based budget, which is controlled by local mgr, creates miserly atmosphere (gender pay equality doesn't exist, little to no financial support for morale-building events). Imbalance of workload and compensation. Lots of people with 10+ years of seniority have left the company in the last 6-12 months.
Advice to Management
Not worth commenting. Management has their own spin on what is good and not so good about the company and the workers. They send out regular surveys, but don't seem to like addressing the negative issues.

review_title: Has Potential to be a "Great Place to Work" but Needs to Improve Culture
pros:
Attempting to implement Integrated Lean Six Sigma IL6S (commonly known as TPM). The structure and tools could significantly improve work environment and performance, if implemented properly and all functional levels support and practice it. 

I really enjoy the products made. 

Many great co-workers.

Being an international company, there are many great resources to use for your development and everyday work, if you choose to find and utilize them. They are typically not promoted or generally shared; you have to search for and ask for them. 

Good pay. 

Great vacation! Started with 20 days of PTO. Every 5yrs, you get 5 more days of PTO.
cons:
High turn-over, especially among management- both within corporate and at plant level. This means priorities and initiatives are frequently changing, creating a "flavor of the month" mentality and lack of interest or commitment to these initiatives among long-term employees. 

Lack of promotion contributes to high turn-over. Tend to hire external candidates, rather than promote internal employees. Management seems to like the idea of hiring from competitors to gain knowledgeable employees who were trained by other companies. They do not invest in training and developing current employees or building skills internally. 


WARNING: they tend to speak highly in interviews and make "promises" to get you in their doors, but then do not keep those promises. If it's important to you, get them to commit to it in writing!

Burn-out is also a huge problem, contributing to high turnover. Especially at the plant level, there is a perception that salaried employees need to work 10+hr days and be readily available to work weekends and odd shifts. Also, with the ever-changing new initiatives, new responsibilities- though often seemingly non-value-added- are frequently added to every role at all functional levels- rarely removing other non-value-added responsibilities. 
Another contributing factor, hard-working employees tend to have to absorb the responsibilities of others- whether it be picking up the slack of another employee or fulfilling the responsibilities of a former employee who will not be replaced. Usually this tactic is easy savings. As a supervisor, I absorbed the role of another supervisor who was promoted and chose not to replace himself. As a continuous improvement engineer, I absorbed the role of my manager- who was never replaced. I was also not given a promotion or raise for assuming my manager's responsibilities. 

Poor communication. 

Lack of appreciation. 

Celebration of or recognition for successes is rare. "Failure" is not viewed as a learning opportunity. Due to poorly executed "high accountability", there is a general sense of fear of the repercussions of "failure" among motivated employees- until they became burnt out and just don't care about work anymore. This has caused some of my co-workers to be extremely cautious- not open and honest- and non-committing of their communications, often leading to miscommunications. It also frequently causes coworkers to "throw others under the bus" to defend themselves. 

Distinguishable "Cliques".
Advice to Management
The company has great values and ideas- especially with IL6S! Focus on living those values and properly executing IL6S. IL6S clearly provides a pathway to take you to the next level! Believe in it! Believe in the pillar work processes and follow through with them- especially Rewards and Recognition, Skill Matrix, Kaizen. Don't just ask for 100% Engagement because you are being told to- truly want it, believe in it, and embrace it!

With an open-mind, evaluate the high-turnover rate. Utilize your findings to change your culture. You are capable of being a "Great Place to Work" if everyone practices what they preach. (ie: "Celebrate the Red!" “Servant Leadership,” "Be Open and Inclusive," "Learn Do Teach," "Plan Do Check Act") 

Best Wishes! I know that you can make the change. You have the tools! Believe and Follow Through!!
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt:
The company has great values and ideas- especially with IL6S! Focus on living those values and properly executing IL6S. IL6S clearly provides a pathway to take you to the next level! Believe in it! cons:
Need more comunication between upper management and field representetives. Managers need to return phone calls and employee request in a timely manner. Also, scheduling time alloted needs to be focused more on doing a complete store job rather than being concerned with meeting given time allotments.
Advice to Management
Try to project to the field that you care about solving all the obstacles that they face out in the marketplace. Such as providing adequate help on heavy case days.....not having employees travel extreme distances to their 1st stops in the mournings. Knowing what town employees live in so they can schedules them accordingly. Not having different salesmen and especially merchandisers crossing territories and working in more than one territory. Don't take a merchandiser from their home area and put someone else in that area and move the home person sometimes where the other person is coming from. Use bonuses more effectively.....let employees know that they met their goals and that they will receive that bonus. Instead of just looking at your payroll check and seeing that you got the quarter bonus or whatever bonus it may be.

review_title: Marketing downsizes and reorgs every year
pros:
Smart people who in the right structure could do great things. 
Certain roles can provide sound marketing experience 
Great brands
cons:
Matrix org structure with no clear understanding of each team’s role. 
No accountability or ownership of brands. Commercial, Equity, Innovation, Activation teams are constantly stepping on each other’s toes and pointing fingers rather than working in harmony to grow the brands. 
Matrix org does not facilitate development of junior talent as teams are operating in silos with limited interaction with their managers and without an enterprise view of their brands/portfolio. 
Failure to commit to a consistent strategic agenda: renovations, well being, indulgence, etc. 
Management believes (through their actions not talking points) that the North American confectionary and biscuit categories are in perpetual decline and will continue to cut to grow profits: continued downsizing, cutting DSD like Kellogg’s, cutting Advertising spend, cutting innovation investment, downgrading marketing salaries
Failure to leverage ‘Enjoy Life’ portfolio to drive growth
Advice to Management
You have talented people. Create a org structure of brand ownership and clear accountability.

advice_to_mgmt: You have talented people. Create a org structure of brand ownership and clear accountability.

pros: Very Rewarding, Great Pay, Flexible hours, Creative Atmosphere
cons:
Depend on locations, the management can be unfair and stressful
Advice to Management
I started with the company as a part timer in 2015. I was promoted in 7 months. I loved the management in St. Louis. Very caring, communication was great. When my car stop working, my supervisor picked me up and we worked together to complete stores. When I had questions, my supervisor listened and solved issues that needed to be addressed. I've transfer 3 times, went to Savannah area. The management wasnt as family oriented however as long as you were making your sale goals, they were okay with you. Also, I appreciate the training and sales techniques Ive learned in Savannah. I transfer to Atlanta and wasnt their too long simply because management do things different. I was under a lot of pressure when it came to work load and getting done under 40 hours with little help and staffing. I also felt like I wasn't able to use my talents like I was able to do at Savannah and St. Louis. My advice for only Atlanta management is to value your good workers who are willing to complete the job of those who lack. Focus on hiring more staff for sales representative territory who are over worked simply because theirs not enough staff and current staff that doesn't complete their job.

I've transfer 3 times, went to Savannah area. The management wasnt as family oriented however as long as you were making your sale goals, they were okay with you. Also, I appreciate the training and sales techniques Ive learned in Savannah. I transfer to Atlanta and wasnt their too long simply because management do things different. I was under a lot of pressure when it came to work load and getting done under 40 hours with little help and staffing. I also felt like I wasn't able to use my talents like I was able to do at Savannah and St. Louis. My advice for only Atlanta management is to value your good workers who are willing to complete the job of those who lack. Focus on hiring more staff for sales representative territory who are over worked simply because theirs not enough staff and current staff that doesn't complete their job.
Helpfu

review_title: Trident Gum Factory. Amazingly terrible job.
pros: Great place to work if you enjoy tyrannical employers who will never recognize hard work. Especially great if you are the type of person that likes to keep their nose brown.
cons:
Abhorrent working conditions akin to working in a coal mine. Enough talc in the air to choke and the mint is so strong it's like slathering icy hot all over your body while your nose is running and you are involuntarily crying. Their way of dealing with employee morale is to clamp down a little harder when you are unhappy and "if you don't like it, there's the door" (yes, I have heard this more than once). Sometimes the mandate to work on Saturday comes 5 minutes before you leave on Friday, although after 18 straight months of Saturdays you come to expect it. I have personally watched them break labor laws and lie to their employees about what the laws actually state, only to change their tune after complaints are made. And then pick up the same line of lies later. Everyone makes the same wage per labor grade, which encourages many people to do very little, and the max labor grade is not comparable to many manufacturing jobs in the area. If you are offered the opportunity to become a team lead, they call it a developmental position. This is where you take on all of the responsibilities of a manager/supervisor while getting paid the same wage you were previously making, and regularly string people along for periods of years or until you are fed up with it and step down. If you are able to befriend someone in senior management, they might create a meaningless job title for you which has lead to a significantly top heavy structure filled with dead weight.
Advice to Management
The only reason it has not been managed into the ground is the shear profitability of making gum. My advice to you, keep your job because you would not last a month in a properly managed facility.
Helpful (5
advice_to_mgmt: The only reason it has not been managed into the ground is the shear profitability of making gum. My advice to you, keep your job because you would not last a month in a properly managed facility.

review_title: Warehouse hours will run you into the ground
pros: The pay was good, the guys were all pretty cool.
cons:
I have almost 20 years of warehouse experience so I'm used to hard work and would still be at Mondelez Int. in Weston, Fl if it weren't for the hours. Yes the work is hard, but it would be OK if they had regular hours. You get there in the morning and find out how many trucks have to be loaded for the day. They can't keep employees so they are short-staffed so then we would have maybe 6 of us to operate 3 lines. One person walking up and down the line with a headset pulling all the product and another at the end loading everything on a pallet and wrapping the pallet. Both jobs are a pretty good workout for each person. It probably takes about 3 to 4 hours to load a truck with approximately 20 pallets. Sometimes longer. We had 10 trucks to load yesterday so 2 lines had 3 trucks and one line (the fastest guys) had 4 trucks to load. That right there kinda sucks, because the two guys who are always the fastest ones there always get done first so they get the next trucks paperwork and have to do another truck. They are the fastest and they are very good also so it sucks that they have to get the most work. They should be rewarded not punished. Everybody there talked about how the hours were so bad and after looking at warehouse reviews from all over you would think management would try to do something about it. Another thing management should consider is any miss-picks are probably done when the guys are going into their 11th, 12th, 13th etc. hour and they are tired and sweating profusely and dropping boxes.
Advice to Management
You need to hire more people and have more lines running so the guys can get out of there at a decent hour and not pulling 15-17 hour work days. The thing that everybody talked about all the time when I was there was how the hours were killing them.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: You need to hire more people and have more lines running so the guys can get out of there at a decent hour and not pulling 15-17 hour work days. The thing that everybody talked about all the time when I was there was how the hours were killing them.

pros:
Classic CPG organization - marketing centric with smart, driven marketers at every level. Most came from Kraft Foods as part of the transition from 1 company to 2, (myself included) and during my tenure much of the operation procedure was still based in Kraft culture and strategic framing. 
Lots of opportunity to lead different brands in both biscuit and confectionary and make an impact on some of the biggest brands in the world like Oreo. 
Great culture with focus on giving back to the community, work-life-balance, and a healthy level of just having fun in the office. Work hard, play hard. 
Global opportunities are the norm vs. a "one-off".
cons:
Every year, another re-org. As Irene Rosenfeld looked for ways to unlock growth - particularly by focusing on global opportunities for well established domestic brands and creating synergies between regional and global marketing, the structure of the organization changed. It skewed heavy on the global side, then swung back to a more regional structure. There were lay-offs and remaining marketers were spread thin. This isn't a Mondelez specific phenomena however, and in general marketing will continue to evolve to become more nimble in the digital era.
Advice to Management
Keep investing in the brands and bringing in/up the strong marketing talent to lead them. This is a world class organization and a gold star for others to follow.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: Keep investing in the brands and bringing in/up the strong marketing talent to lead them. This is a world class organization and a gold star for others to follow.

pros:
The positives outweigh the negatives. As with any company the work load and responsibilities increase. Companies want more from their employees. With that being said, yes, it is a lot of responsibility. Achieve your objective, direct employees under you both full time and part time Merchandisers. Ultimately you are responsible for a million dollar business.
Pros are: flexibility, benefits, company car for sales reps, vacation time, occasional team building activities, fast paced environment.
cons:
If you are not a self starter and do not take the initiative to go above and beyond you will not be recognized. Work hours can be long. There is no set "work hours". The day is done when you have finished all of your tasks for the day. There is never a week with less than 40 hours. Most weeks are over 40 hours. Hours of administrative time, working at home, (giving merchandisers directions, sales planning, trouble shooting) often go unpaid, due to them only allowing 2 hours of admin time a week. 
Computer scheduling app, IDEPLOY, is a joke. Unrealistic work loads. Plenty of Downfalls to the system
Advice to Management
Let the sales rep schedule their help as needed. Fix the IDEPLOY system. Have more team building activities, show more appreciation for dedicated employees who go above and beyond and need minimal support.

advice_to_mgmt: Let the sales rep schedule their help as needed. Fix the IDEPLOY system. Have more team building activities, show more appreciation for dedicated employees who go above and beyond and need minimal support.

pros:
- Great brands, both in the US and abroad.
- I gained great training in CPG marketing (although I can't say the same for junior employees who have recently joined the company), and the company brand still carries weight externally.
- I worked with some of the smartest people I've ever met, and I had some really great, inspirational managers (middle management only - senior management is a totally different story).
- Compensation in marketing (in the US, at least) is above market average.
cons:
- Career pathing in marketing has fallen off a cliff. What used to be a world of opportunity is now very limited, both in terms of geography (very few global roles remain) and scope (marketing roles are now overly specialized in the regions). 
- Most big CPGs are bogged down by process, but Mondelez is even more so. It's no wonder the company is not hitting its growth targets - bureaucracy and politics are major inhibitors to growth here.
- While I can't say the culture is bad, I can say it is nonexistent - which is almost worst. There's no camaraderie among colleagues in the NA business unit, because everyone is miserable and no one wants to be there anymore. It's sad to see such talented people so unmotivated.
Advice to Management
It's time for changes at the top. Missing targets, constant restructures, and being up on the chopping block with constant press around takeovers is a sign that something big needs to change.

advice_to_mgmt: It's time for changes at the top. Missing targets, constant restructures, and being up on the chopping block with constant press around takeovers is a sign that something big needs to change.

review_title: Senior salary staff member in operations
pros:
Mondelez pays higher than most manufacturing in North American for salaried positions above a supervisor. 
Aside from Mondelez being a completely unknown name, we produce the most well known cookie (Oreo) which is instantaneously recognized and and always fun to talk about.
cons:
Absolutely no training and no support!
They pay higher in plants because they have no understanding of production or how to build sustainable teams, which is resulting in unimaginable amounts of turn over.
There is always a divide between corporate and actual bakery/plant operations but this company has what resembles a caste system and the folks in plants are treated like "untouchables".
The health insurance is a joke.
There is no sense of work-life balance or human value for leaders in the plants.
Advice to Management
To those of you who have spent little to no time on the production floor, please try it. Learn the people and what they deal with on a daily basis so you can make more educated decisions.
Redirect your "investing" in operations. Buzz words and complicated boards are not what builds success. Layers of corporate "help" in terms of levels upon levels of people writing reports will not build capabilities. Invest in training! I mean real, hands on training with informative CBT courses linked to hands on floor experience. This will build competence and capability in your leadership to manage the change that is needed to make this company what it once was.
Helpfu

pros: Decent wages for most starting levels and standard health benefits. Co-workers are for the most part good...unfortunately it ends there
cons:
By far the most resturing company I've ever seen. The do more with less attitude is at a high especially when it comes to jobs. They reduce headcount and throw another job at you to do with your own but still only pay you for one. Four years now, no raises for the hourly employees (you get a lump sum check based off some number) that is split over several months at high tax rate and doesn't consider any overtime. Management placates employee concerns by saying they are working on them but then something else always takes precedence. Corporate managers are always looking to get any extra pennies they can squeeze out of the companies for their bonus'. The CEO make 20 million in bonus' while the worker jumps through hoops of fire to get a check that MAY make then a single week of pay. No advancement in the company...they are happy to let you stay at a low level but let you work the job of someone who is supposed to work at a higher salary (and the call it "Developmental" for over 2 years) and then just hire from an outside source. Instead of putting people into jobs they know how to do or are exceptional at they go by seniority (even in a non-union plant) and most job opportunities they post already have candidates for them pre-selected. No more company cookouts or anything as the Senior management has limited the plant to spending only 40$ a year per person for any perks.
Advice to Management
Treat your people like you want to be treated...fairly and honestly. Don't keep making them 2 or more jobs for the same low pay, give raises and give them off individual performances NOT a group raise...quit with the lump sum raises and make the BONUS program a little more equitable to those working in the trenches not just those behind the office doors. Moral in the company is at an all time low...bring back some company cookouts This is why the turnover is high.

review_title: The juice isn't worth the squeeze...stay away.
pros:
- Excellent benefits (401k, Dental, Medical, Vision etc)
- Perks (Company car, gas card, cell phone, tablet, bonus plan, quarterly employee appreciation gifts)
- Great people, lifelong friends; some of the hardest working people I think I've ever met
- Great stepping stone on your resume
- Management can, in most cases, be relatable and treats you with dignity and respects you as a living/breathing human being
- Free Cookies!
cons:
- Workload is ridiculous :

Perception does not match reality. 10-12 hr HARD labor expected to be conpleted in an 8 hour time frame. It's a flawed system and if you're a merchandiser, you better hope you get a professional sales representative that doesn't overwork you and never appreciates your willingness to be a team player.

- Upper management disconnect:

Greedy investors and head choppers at the top demonstrate a lack of sense or empathy to reality: Sales goals are 90% unattainable.


Your customers :

Industry clients like Kroger and Safeway are used to top tier service- so your all is never enough. If you like your phone ringing off the hook at 5 in the morning because a load hasn't been worked- this is the company for you. Customers cry about everything from backstock, to why they're not the first ones being serviced on a non service day. You'll never make everyone happy no matter what you do.

Absolutely NO WORK/LIFE balance:


If you're a family man, plan to be one or want to work 8 hour days to avoid traffic, this is NOT your company. You 85% of the time never get our the time you should. If you call your manager or sales rep for help , it can be draining experience with constant interrogation about why you couldn't throw up countless amounts of cases in an allocated amount of short time. Drive time/store issues are never taken into consideration: broken system. Say goodbye to your social life...you're a slave to your job.

No structure: 

See above. The company needs to revamp outdated scheduling system that is not followed anyway due to geographic and time flaws. Management never addresses the elephant in the room of poor scheduling. In some cases it adds work to your day.

There is no time in the day to "sell in" extra product. The company just restructured due to investor pressure but wants to utilize sales reps in multi selling/merchandising roles with lack of or horrid help which decreases sales revenue and just burns people out causing them to want to leave the company altogether.

Workload : 

Do you want to be a glorified merchandiser? This is the job for you. 

Wake up at 3-4am, throw upwards of about 300-500 cases with an expectation to write orders, build rapport and sell extra product- not gonna happen. Look at your back rooms! Stop forcing reps to sell in more oreos and chips ahoy when your back rooms are a mess.


Promotion? Good luck.

It's a who you know business. Some promotions don't match the work of the individual being promoted. The continued "passing of the torch " to unqualified individuals with zero business ethics is making a revolving door and your best people are walking through it!

High changeovers due to moral discontent. 

Changing landscape:

GMO, Organic and Glutten free solutions are not being addressed properly by this company. It will drive sales to the ground. Good Thins isn't enough.

Job instability:

The company just went through some major changes this year (as it does every few years). People with the company for decades lost their jobs due to shipment of jobs to othwe countries or were demoted due to cuts- more to come soon.
Advice to Management
I can't stress this enough : LISTEN to your PEOPLE. Upper management is slave to the ends instead of the means of making quota.

Instead of throwing unachievable sales goals for payouts we will never be rewarded due to lack of performance, top managers need to work hand in hand with the people at the "bottom of the totem pole" to truly grasp how long it actually takes to throw a load or deal with store managers.

Stop cramming numbers down our throats when our backrooms look like a natural disaster and the store cannot take more.

You are losing a lot of undervalued, overworked and underpaid people sacrificing family, relationships, goals and aspirations to get by not getting written up for first world mistakes.

Unless you address some of the assertions explained here, Mondelez international will continue to be a revolving door of disgruntled employees who find better paying jobs that don't suck the life out of them physically and mentally.
Helpful (17
advice_to_mgmt:
I can't stress this enough : LISTEN to your PEOPLE. Upper management is slave to the ends instead of the means of making quota.

Instead of throwing unachievable sales goals for payouts we will never be rewarded due to lack of performance, top managers need to work hand in hand with the people at the "bottom of the totem pole" to truly grasp how long it actually takes to throw a load or deal with store managers.

employee_status: Sales Service Representative in Oakdale, CA
pros: The independence of this job is what's best most of the time. A ton of the job is driving, usually not far. So it's cool to drive around independently from location to location. The work is easy, and for the most part the people are nice to deal with. In my experience, management and Sales Reps are pleasant to talk to and are mostly sympathetic to your situation. The training can be limited, but it's honestly so easy to pick up.
cons:
For Merchandisers or Sales Service Reps, the hours aren't the greatest. You work most if not all weekends. Occasionally, it's hard to get hours during the week. Work can be very repetitive. Training can be hard to come by. Communication can be hard at times, as it's all over the phone. Sometimes it's hard to get a hold of upper management. Sometimes, expectations, especially during holidays are unrealistic. Pay is a little higher than most for merchandisers. Reimbursement for gas mileage however, is pretty low. Lots of wear and tear on your vehicle over time.
Advice to Management
Improve rates for gas mileage reimbursement. Make sure all the territories have more than enough people to cover.

pros: Job pays considerably more than competitors in existing market. Stable company with great growth and shareholder visibility. Margins are consistently increasing quarter to quarter with major CapEx investments being made across the globe for expansion and acquisition
cons:
Very lean organization that undervalues work-life balance making it a difficult place to work. Overall morale is low and company values are not perceived as being supported by existing leadership. Retention is low creating openings for external talent that is young and willing to zig-zag across the organization. Existing leadership is seemingly changing to a global scale so if you are not able to speak a second language this could be a hindrance to long-term growth
Advice to Management
Focus more on work-life balance initiatives that will improve overall morale making it a great place to work. Establish robust development plans with tangible growth opportunities for internal candidates within the organization. Do not lean out the organization to the point it cannot sustain long-term growth.

pros: I really can't think of any pros. This place drains the life out of you in a short period of time.
cons:
Abusive, condescending, critical managers who are too busy micro-managing to let you do your job. All innovative thinking is squelched as they beat you down and leave you feeling incompetent and wondering when you will be fired. They squeeze people in like sardines to save money and then expect you to get your work done. Unhelpful co-workers act like you are making them go out of their way to help you learn and do your job properly. Co-workers take short-cuts to get the job done and are heralded as "wonderful" employees while you are portrayed as slow and incompetent because you are thorough and accurate. It is a "figure it out" mentality with little training and just do it with no questions asked.
Advice to Management
Do not hire professional, experienced people and then not let them do their job. Stop the babysitting and treat people with the respect that they deserve. Could be a "nice place to work" as your company's motto suggests, but only after you look at your current terrible management and clean house

Helpfu

pros:
Company at times can have fun at meetings and make you feel like you are part of something big.
Company car. Free cookies and crackers.
Good amount of PTO.
cons:
When I started with Nabisco they were owned by Kraft. I really enjoyed the job then. There was a lot of flexibility to allow for some work life balance. In 2013 they spun off from Kraft to become their own company Mondelez, based in Canada with brands like cadbury, sour patch, halls and trident. Almost immediately they started taking things away. First it was the announcement that we all were loosing our annual bonuses, then they took a week of PTO away from every rep(can you believe that?). Then the one thing that was great, the company car, was downgrade from a nice ford Fusion to a tin can Cruze or Ford focus. 
But it didn't stop there. The sales objectives got so high that most reps could not make bonus. Mondelez is setting the sales projection high just to please the stock holders and we are left holding the bag. The latest cost move they employed is to ad 5 stores to all reps and demote reps that don't live in their territory to full time merchandisers. The morale between reps has never been so low in my time with the company. I expect a large exodus of sales reps. Many reps have lost routes they had serviced for 10+ years and moved to low performing routes with no chance of making a bonus. Without bonus, the job is not worth all the hard work and I mean hard work. Base salary will range from 36,000 to 40,000 depending on qualifications. Nabisco faces some serious challenges ahead. The world is eating better and lets face it, their products are on most parents do not buy list. They are trying to get creative to secure the lost revenue. Cutting employee cost is at the top of their list. I would not think of this as a growing company as a perspective new hire, but a shrinking one.
Advice to Management
Quit trying to squeeze so much out of the bottom line at the expense of the employees. They are the ones selling and putting the money in the bank that pays your salary, let them sell and keep them happy. Then the numbers will come in for you.
Helpful (14
advice_to_mgmt: Quit trying to squeeze so much out of the bottom line at the expense of the employees. They are the ones selling and putting the money in the bank that pays your salary, let them sell and keep them happy. Then the numbers will come in for you.

pros:
I have been merchandising for several years and in all types of fields. ( Gift Cards, Grocery Resets, Electronics, Hardware Stores & more ) 

I'm young & fit as well but I have to say expect this to be one of the most demanding jobs and stressful you probably will come by.

You must be there around 5 AM on delivery days which are Mon, Wed & Fri and if you are not there on the exact dot of time the stores will call your boss and complain on you like they are literally dying and having a panic attack because someone is not there to put out crackers. yes it happened when I first started a few times I hate to admit. 

Every manager is different I'm sure but the one I got is a major micro manager to the extreme!! Now my manager is a really nice person but still micro manages 24/7 even when you are not on the schedule or even working. They constantly send texts over and over telling you to do the most simple & mundane things that you probably already did way before they even texted you. Making it seem as you are mentally challenged.

They constantly demand you work better but also quicker because you are claiming to many hours, stores treat you like you are a complete utter useless, brain damaged and not worth living human being ( except Walmart ) 

Do you really want me to continue? Yes it's seriously that bad.

At this job you actually hope to have someone work with you because you really truly will need the help because it is so much to do! BUT when you do ask for help from your co workers they say the can't or even worst when you ask your manager they simply tell you N O 

And when your coworkers aren't telling you they can't help they are texting photos of your untrained work such as bad placement of items, damaged items, boxes stacked wrong on pallets, pallets not condensed correctly, pallets not shrink wrapped correctly ARE all being sent to your boss. Basically they are snitching on you BUT keep in mind no one taught you how to do any of the above mentioned stuff and you really had to learn from your mistakes or you would not last here for long.

Another thing is the scheduling, you get your weekly log of work to do usually about a week ahead of time so you can plan out your week of off days and days you are working and even which stores you are going to go to! Sounds great right? Well it would be if that's how it actually happens. What always happens is you get a text from your boss around 8 or 9 the night before and they tell you where you need to go and it never ever matches the schedule. So let's say you was only supposed to work 1 store so you might plan something that day for yourself or family but then out of nowhere they have you working 3 and the days your supposed to work 3 they change it up on you the last minute and your only working one. Happens literally every single day. 

You are allowed to take lunches on your own time but more then once as soon as I went on lunch, got some food and was putting the fork to my mouth to eat my phone literally starting ringing and my boss is on the other end screaming asking where am I because the store complained I left OR my boss is at the store doing a check up on me. 

It's a true nightmare majority of the time
cons:
Everything I mentioned above, you get paid between $10-$12 dollars and its really not to much worth it unless you really don't have anything better
Advice to Management
Treat people like people, actually take the time out to train, don't let other members of the team constantly nag on other members. 

Don't let the store control you or your employees
Helpful (3

Treat people like people, actually take the time out to train, don't let other members of the team constantly nag on other members.

pros: Casual work environment (maybe too casual?), recognizable brands, ability to telecommute, half days on Fridays during summer, outstanding 401K match (4.5% contributed automatically, plus a match on 75% of your first 6% contributed). Health benefits seem OK, although I never use them other than annual check-ups.
cons:
Nobody really knows the company name, lack of work-life balance, perpetual reorganization and downsizing, overly aggressive targets (which manifest in low bonuses), extremely limited career paths. Very top-heavy organization, though management often says there's an "overheads problem" ... which they've gone to the extreme to combat (no expensing dinners for late nights, no team outings, etc.)
Advice to Management
Pay attention to the younger employees. Seems like most employees were "lifers" before the Kraft-Mondelez company split. The younger folks have no pension or incentive to stay when there's little development opportunity, low annual raises (1-2%), and no pension. Quid pro quo.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Pay attention to the younger employees. Seems like most employees were "lifers" before the Kraft-Mondelez company split. The younger folks have no pension or incentive to stay when there's little development opportunity, low annual raises (1-2%), and no pension. Quid pro quo.

pros: Great benefits, 401K with matching, low-priced insurance. Awesome brands that are leaders in the category. My co-workers were amazing. Company car with personal and business gas paid for. If sales and manual labor is your thing, and you have no plans on doing anything else with your career, this job is perfect.
cons:
Not really a sales job, it's mostly physical labor. This goes for Senior Sales Service Reps and Sales Reps too. Broken promises by management. They want Sales Reps to have college degrees, so they recruit from universities and give so much hope that you can make it to corporate, they will help you out along the way. In reality, there is little possibility of moving up unless you want to stick with it at the retail level for a decade or more. Low morale. Unrealistic sales goals. Management was a disorganized mess. Grocery managers can be rude and very difficult to work with. Merchandising help is not always up-to-par, so you're just doing more work to fix what is wrong. Also not enough merchandising help. Company is still restructuring, so budgets are being cut, jobs are being cut, and there is less mobility. Zero work/life balance. You are always on call, even on weekends when something goes wrong, you have to send out notes every night, and work with many merchandisers who don't have accountability for a territory of stores, so they call out sick or can't work at a certain time and leave you scrambling.
Advice to Management
Don't go to college campuses and pour out false hope and promises. This is not work for a college grad, and while I understand the "working from the bottom up" mentality, we shouldn't be stuck in this position for years. Get organized, be realistic, and be upfront and "tell it like it is."
Helpful (9
advice_to_mgmt: Don't go to college campuses and pour out false hope and promises. This is not work for a college grad, and while I understand the "working from the bottom up" mentality, we shouldn't be stuck in this position for years. Get organized, be realistic, and be upfront and "tell it like it is."

pros: Great co-workers who genuinely want to do a great job and contribute to the success of Mondelez. The brand portfolio is excellent and second to none.
cons:
Some functional areas are significantly understaffed and the existing staff are working long hours to get their jobs done. Additionally, many administrative functions have been outsourced to 3rd party companies and/or moved to offshore locations where communication skills of the staff are extremely poor and where these offshore staff work off a script that they cannot deviate from. In addition, the people in these offshore locations are not nearly as knowledgeable or competent as the onshore staff. Hence, numerous calls to these offshore locations must be made before a problem is resolved. Accounts Payable, is probably the weakest area with the lowest customer service satisfaction rate for both the staff of Mondelez and for vendors trying to figure out why invoices are not being paid.
Advice to Management
Focus on developing onshore staff and repatriate the offshore functions to the US. Add staff to the Accounts Payable area once the current offshore staff is moved to the US so that invoices can be paid on a timely basis and correctly the first time. review_title: Good if you view it as a stepping stone
pros: Excellent PTO (if you can use it), great 401k match, good cross border learning
cons:
Where do I begin..under Cadbury the workforce was small but well compensated and the growth and innovation fostered a profitable company with a friendly work environment. Kraft came along and slowed the company down immensely. At first, they added a whole bunch of make-work jobs, mostly in the backoffice when they downgraded to an older version of SAP. Flash forward to today and nearly everyone I started with has either been cut or has found better jobs elsewhere. 

During my time in Research I've seen project after project killed due to cost and only the ones which promoted cost cutting with cheaper (usually Chinese) ingredients move forward. Meanwhile, the smaller (usually private) competitors climb further and further ahead since they try to answer the customers needs/wants and actually roll out fun new products.

Meanwhile the Zero Based Budgeting and the cost cutting mentality has created a culture of fear where no one dares to speak up for fear of losing their jobs in the next round of firing. Some people even blatantly back stab and sabotage their coworkers in order to curry favor and protect themselves. No workplace is perfect but between the lack of emphasis on growth and the relentless costcutting I don't see the company lasting more than a few years before being bought out by someone more competent.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the current Executive team and find leaders who knows how to manage costs but still retain good talent and fund innovation and actually create growth. You can't just cut your way to growth.
Helpful (6
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of the current Executive team and find leaders who knows how to manage costs but still retain good talent and fund innovation and actually create growth. You can't just cut your way to growth.

review_title: NOT a great place to work
pros: Decent salary, some benefits are nice, good people to work with
cons:
Arrogant abusive managers, hypocrisy, little to no respect for technology people in the IT organization, if you are considered "too" technical you are a target for elimination
Advice to Management
If you want Mondelez to be a "Great Place to Work" (which is a motto of yours) then you should treat your people better. You had a long and drawn out process of layoffs in 2014. You had people worry for nearly 9 months about whether they were on the "list" before finally dropping the axe on them. You even had the nerve to deliver the news to people on the same day that you had your fall celebration day festival in Deerfield. While some people were eating brats and drinking beer, others were being told they no longer had a job. Very cruel and inconsiderate to say the least. You also condone abusive behavior by managers. There is little to no growth opportunity whatsoever. You work your people extremely hard during your tough times and then as soon as things slow down and are under control, you start trying to outsource their jobs as fast as you can. In nutshell, you just don't care for your people. Senior mangers just look to axe people all the time to get a fatter bonus and a promotion. Sad, so sad how you treat the people that made you what your are today.

review_title: Comfortable but few Opportunities for Growth
pros: Mondelez is a very comfortable place to work. The IS department has done an incredible job making work/life balance easy for employees. As long as you have an internet connection, you can work from anywhere in the world. Many white collar colleagues work from home every Friday, and some only step foot in the office 1-2x a month. Some even "work" from their vacations to skirt the limits on PTO days. That's not to say it's easy work; many colleagues are expected to do the same work that was managed by two or three different roles prior to the Kraft split. Night and weekend work is almost a given during most projects. Pay is extremely high because the corporate locations are usually an hour or more from major urban centers which hurts recruiting. Benefits are good but have been reduced substantially in recent years (pensions are no longer available to new employees; healthcare plans have gone to high deductible models; the 401k matching has been reduced.) So, you get a decent work/life balance thanks to the mobility options, nice benefits, and a high-paying job, but in general one should expect there to be much in the way of growth opportunity beyond that. It's a good place to be comfortable, which is great for the right kind of person.
cons:
The company is almost constantly embarking on an organizational restructuring in some form or fashion. That means that annually colleagues are laid off and those who remain must pick up the slack. With the recent focus on cost control, there are very few job openings in many of the white collar departments, and often the openings that do come up are filled from outside the company. There are very few advancement opportunities into management and many people find themselves in specialist positions without clear career progression. This tends to drag down morale and most people seem content to do their assigned jobs and get out of the office as quickly as possible most days. It is hard to say there is really a culture at Mondelez; something is just missing.
Advice to Management
The "top down" mandates (particularly in regards to organizational design) seem to run counter to the "open and inclusive" value for Mondelez. Rather than deciding the career futures of employees in metaphorical smoke-filled rooms, HR and senior management should make an actual effort to know the wants and needs of the people they lead.
Helpful (6

Rather than deciding the career futures of employees in metaphorical smoke-filled rooms, HR and senior management should make an actual effort to know the wants and needs of the people they lead.

review_title: Great Brands with No Job Security and Below Average Management
pros:
1. Brands
2. Co workers
3. Above average benefits and competitive compensation
4. Encourages multi culture hiring and very friendly to women
5. Flexible work from home schedule
cons:
1. No job security. Ongoing restructuring, high number of layoffs, performance doesn't create security, recent re org eliminated mostly men aged in the low 50's. Very very political atmosphere.
2. Limited Career Opportunities. Layoffs eliminate positions that could offer career advancement
3. Mid and upper middle management often have little management training and often limited understanding of their function. Decisions take too far long. Inexperience leads to heavy red tape and the bureaucracy can be overwhelming. 
4. Senior management has created a false sense of camaraderie. Meetings and town halls show us faking enthusiasm. Fear of telling it like it is. Seeming arrogance by senior leaders. No one cares that our global strategy officer also has to manage his old north american president job. Ongoing changes leaves us feeling they have no direction and just making changes to appease investors. 
5. Work life balance: 50+ hour weeks are common. Elimination of administrative assistants adds many hours of tedious work. Common to not use 10 vacation days each year. Productivity is constantly being disrupted by communication of upcoming org changes
6. Open office structure has further reduced productivity. Everyone in a cubicle separated by 6 inch wall. You can see and hear everything everyone on the floor is doing
Advice to Management
Live the values you publish and recognize your employees want to love this company. Stop the incessant accusations that our company's expenses are twice that of peer companies.
Helpful (11
advice_to_mgmt: Live the values you publish and recognize your employees want to love this company. Stop the incessant accusations that our company's expenses are twice that of peer companies.

Helpfu

pros: Living wage and benefits. The jobs are very challenging and rewarding. Old world mentality with a distinct expectation towards success and profit. Independent opportunity based management processes within a total world direction.
cons:
Cut throat atmosphere with a big worry every day of injury. The career I was in was a Union Stationary Engineer position within the Portland Nabisco Plant. The job has a 200 pound repetitive lifting capacity job description. If you are injured, and you report it properly, your career will be destroyed. You will be harassed and degraded. Thank god for workers compensation laws. This company policy's for management is to treat their injured workers like the enemy. In the six years I was there, the plant manager/lower level managers and maintenance managers were changed numerous times leaving a huge divide between management and union employees.
Advice to Management
Invest in the long term (management and lower level) employee retention. Get away from the current cutthroat safety processes towards a more self reflective responsibility platform. This Company is like so many others who do not value it's employees and focuses on giving huge bonuses to their top executives.

employee_status: Brand Management in East Hanover, NJ
review_title: Not always as happy as the brands they manage
pros: Mondelez certainly wants to try new things and has had some great marketing around its brands because of their willingness to work with agency partners and push forward. They allow employees to move around to different departments if they can prove a genuine interest (and get the necessary graduate education for certain roles). It's definitely a good name for the resume. Fun brands to work on. Work life balance is okay (not the best in the industry but certainly not the worst).
cons:
Some teams are great to be part of while others leave quite a lot to be desired. People are promoted because it's time rather than because they have the skills; this is particularly a problem when it comes to managing others. There are some people who truly understand the business but do not know how to manage a team yet they are managing teams and brands because they've been working for a certain number of years. The worst manager I've worked for was at Mondelez. She clearly did not know how to motivate others or foster collaboration, but in all fairness I do not believe that Mondelez ever trained her to be a good manager. There's also quite a bit of internal competition that is more about schmoozing than who is the most qualified (though this is typical of larger organizations). Along those lines, while having Mondelez on a resume shows others you're a good worker, they also assume you're cutthroat because that's the culture Mondelez portrays. 

I often noticed a disconnect between my direct manager and her manager, which made it hard to do my job since they were not communicating effectively. It was to the point where I felt I should ask my manager's manager before going forward with a task because her opinion mattered more. Unfortunately I wasn't the only person who felt this way - several others in the organization saw this same disconnect within their teams making it hard to truly collaborate and understand the goals they were aiming for.

Finally, there's a lot of pressure internally to cut those margins and change downward trends. This can be kind of wearing on people and (while very important) should not be the end all be all of the company.
Advice to Management
Don't simply train people how to do a task, but train your employees how to be effective leaders. Understand that some people (no matter how business savvy) should not lead others. Also don't allow for misalignment of goals within a single team! Focus perhaps on more open communication within teams to have thorough dialogues to clear up any issues. Lastly, know what pressures do and do not need to make their way all the way down the chain.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Don't simply train people how to do a task, but train your employees how to be effective leaders. Understand that some people (no matter how business savvy) should not lead others. Also don't allow for misalignment of goals within a single team! Focus perhaps on more open communication within teams to have thorough dialogues to clear up any issues. review_title: Fun at first, but becomes very derivative.
pros: If you work full-time, you get good benefits, have the weekends off, and have a good opportunity to move up in the company. Most of the time you work by yourself with no one breathing down your neck. Gives you the opportunity to explore the city and suburbs more.
cons:

There is a waiting list to be promoted to full-time, which takes a while. The company is not well organized and constantly has problems with managing their employees.
Advice to Management
Improve your logistics management. It looks very bad for the company when big name accounts have a specific product on sale that does very well in volume, but we are out of stock in the warehouse. As a result, the shelf is empty and the sales rep/merchandiser get an ear full about it from store directors.

Within the same breath they implement cost cutting strategies without any adjustment to the objective. With all that being said they have significant moral issues throughout the organization all while leadership continues to add head count at the top while reducing lower tiers of the organization.
Advice to Management
Leadership needs a shake up, not just adding a CGO and other higher level roles. Marketing and product development needs true innovation that does not cannibalize base sales. Calling a line extension incremental over and over will not get it done. In addition the sales organization continues to be rewarded with incentives that drives poor behavior, and then you write them up for doing what you asked them to do (drive sales beyond consumer trends).

review_title: Administrative Assistant position was well defined, and I had freedom to manage my own schedule.
pros: Awesome office in Deerfield, very well set up for employee comfort including massage chairs and stand up desks available. Also have expresso coffee machines--free coffee always. We had on-site help desk for any IT issues, and ergonomic seating, good lighting. Close free parking, great cafeteria, I was a contractor, but thought management treated everyone with respect. We had many parties, celebrations, and lunch-time educational sessions always included a free lunch. Mondelez is a very generous company (offshoot of Kraft Foods)
cons:
People are so busy that they did not leave the building very often. Also the open seating is good but sometimes it gets so noisy that it is difficult to hear if you are in a meeting. Not too many cons!
Advice to Management
It was hard to be a contractor and know I would be leaving because I made great friends. I think you lose some great hard-working potential employees by using so many contract positions. I wanted to stay so badly and they did pay me well.
